question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You should be ready to be completely independent. No one will be telling you exactly what to do, or how to proceed with your project, so make sure you are ready for that. That being said, you won't be doing all that work and planning alone--you'll have a team. But your teammates might be complete opposites from you (personality-wise, work ethic-wise), but that's okay. You'll be glad you got exposure to different people and learned how to work with them.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don't get behind on documentation, and don't be afraid to work outside of class. response_text: The separation between the ideation phase and the prototyping phase was very beneficial, as it was very clear what we were supposed to be working on. I also really enjoyed the tools masteries as they definitely taught me new skills from scratch.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: When asking previous semesters about the level of difficulty, be wary of the people who said the class was easy. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be ready to spend a lot of late nights at the pod!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The start of the course is crucial to your success. If you really want to learn, choose a challenging project, but not a project that will rip your hair out every 30 seconds. Enjoy the tools masteries because that's as good as it's going to get. Grading may vary from instructor but it feels so arbitrary that the rubric might as well not exist. It's just "No Pass, Low Pass, Pass, High Pass". That's the least useful thing a student could use and the feedback seems like they didn't consider any challenges we went through. While we certainly could have followed up with our instructor about grading, the grade we received were so demotivating. Stay strong brave soldier. Choose your project wisely and push through it. Expect to not have any weekends available and have someone you can vent to. It's about to be a wild ride!

response_text:

response_text: You should be ready to be completely independent. No one will be telling you exactly what to do, or how to proceed with your project, so make sure you are ready for that. That being said, you won't be doing all that work and planning alone--you'll have a team. But your teammates might be complete opposites from you (personality-wise, work ethic-wise), but that's okay. You'll be glad you got exposure to different people and learned how to work with them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought the course was really great. I enjoyed the level of formal instruction we had, but my favorite part of the course was absolutely building a project for a real-world client. Sometimes learning about things like the engineering design process or filling out pugh scoring matrices were tedious and annoying, however I recognize that they are valuable learning experiences. The tools mastery was also my favorite part of the course. I'm really grateful for the introduction it provided to 3d printing and laser cutting, as I didn't come from a high school with an engineering program. It would have been nice to have time to complete other modules too, though, such as the Arduino or even woodworking.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The concept of allowing first year engineering students to work with real-world clients on engineering design problems is superb. Being able to experience a taste of engineering consultation and creation is very engaging and builds necessary skills for the professional field. The POD is also a great environment for the course as it provides a perfect stage to experiment and work on engineering problems.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Dr. Bansal was very helpful with providing suggestions on technical aspects of our project (like considerations for materials), strategies for completing the project (like steps to take to advance our brainstorming), and advice on team dynamics (such as setting hard internal deadlines)
The structure of the course was very helpful in learning the engineering design process. Technical memos helped us reflect and plan. Oral presentations helped our group get on the same page about where we were. And a good amount of class time was allotted to the stuff we needed to work on for our actual project.

response_text: This class can be super rewarding but at the same time definitely forces you to find confidence in other places. There is rarely any positive reinforcement so you never really know if you are doing something right or not or if you are actually capable of being here.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a great way to get started in your engineering career. All the different people coming from different backgrounds come together. It is a great way to learn from other people. On top of that, the maker space is extremely welcoming to any ideas, so as long as you can think of it, you can make it come to life.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is so much fun! At times, it can be quite a bit of work especially when trying to wrap up the final prototype, but it's so rewarding!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Always ask for help when you don't know how to do something. Even if you do, still ask for help from peers and professors because engineering is a collaborative process, and I always learned new ways of doing things when I talked to others that improved upon what I thought of by myself. At first, I felt lost in the course because I did not take any engineering classes in high school, so sometimes I had problems that needed more technical knowledge to be solved, and there were materials or techniques to do things that I just did not know existed. I could have solved many of these problems faster if I asked for help earlier. The POD has so many resources, but you won't know any of them are there if you don't ask for help.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the importance of completing research before beginning to engineer a design to a problem, how to use Fusion360 and Arduinos, and how to construct a long term plan for an engineering design project.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a lot of grit and creativity in this course. We were given a large open-ended project, and given guidance on how to break it into smaller pieces with totally creative freedom. I learned to be more independent and responsible in planning. I also learned many technical skills, including how to build a birdhouse, drill, use saws, and 3-D print. I feel much more confident in my position as an engineer and feel more capable to take on future challenges.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: communication, teamwork, problem solving

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class provides the "jump" into the engineering design process that many freshman crave. While freshman might not expect that they have the needed skills to tackle a design problem given by a client, many will surprise themselves with their knowledge. I learned how to overcome failure, how to work with a client, and the benefits of working with a team.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to follow the engineering design process, how to communicate in a team, and how to cope with failure.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three valuable things I learned from this course include creative thinking and techniques to generate new ideas. Valuable skills of teamwork as well as a deeper understanding of the engineering design process were gained.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: One way the instructors facilitated my learning was by utilizing a flipped classroom, where we would learn concepts through videos completed for homework, and apply the concepts in a classroom activity. This allowed us to take a very hands-on approach to our learning. Additionally, the utilization of a real client with a real issue made me feel as if I was a real engineer working for a company.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There is a very big hands off approach, which is very nice as it models how eventually we all have to solve a problem without the answers given to us.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that there were multiple access points to receive help and advice throughout the semester, inlcuding both the professors, TAs, LabRats, etc. The Tools Mastery modules at the beginning of the semester were very helpful to put the course into perspective and also provide us tools to apply in our projects. Learning how to use Trello was also very helpful to kep the project organized.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked how we had videos most weeks that were due the Sunday before the week started. This allowed me to learn the basics of a lot of the engineering design process before my group got to that step. I also really enjoyed how it was hands on, and we built an actual product.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class has many stages and periods of highs and lows. Sometimes it is easygoing and easy coursework/course load, other times it is quite challenging and intense and difficult. It is up to you to manage your own time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is a great, fun way to get involved in the engineering process. Make sure you prioritize having positive relationships with your teammates, since that can make all the difference. Also, be sure to plan weeks in advance, since you never know when things might go wrong.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a lot of fun, but if you're not careful it will take up all of your time. Be careful not to become the person who does most of the work, and don't be the person who never volunteers to do anything. Also, get started on prototyping as soon as possible, even if you don't feel like you have everything you need to start. Decide on a design quickly, and start prototyping your design as soon as possible.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was stimulating because it showed the applicability of each of the course concepts to our real project and challenged us at every turn to employ new skills and types of dialogue. Namely, we learned the language of engineering--how to set up tests, design criteria, technical memos, and communicate design ideas.There was also a lot of trial and error to our learning, as our technical memos initially fell short, but with feedback and support from our mentors, we improved our work drastically by the end of the semester. It also placed the onus on us to divide up work and maintain positive group dynamics--something I haven't had an opportunity to do before. This ensured that each of us learned to compromise and take turns leading effectively and respectfully.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: As an engineer, this is one of the most important courses you will take, as it introduced you to a variety of skilled applicable to engineering jobs and internships and allows you to understand if you truly want to be an engineer. Because of this, my biggest piece of advice is to use the semester as an opportunity to learn as many of these as possible. Many students approach this course believing that the main goal is to produce a successful design, which is not the case. Instead, you should use this semester to capitalize on the opportunities offered by learning all the machines and techniques. These skills will naturally improve your final design, and even if it is not successful, you will leave with a lot more skills than you had previously, which is the biggest success this class has to offer.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would tell them to put in work outside of class to finish the early prototypes as early as possible, as final prototyping started much sooner than we expected. I would also tell them to establish group expectations early on and address those early in case of any potential difficulties. I would also tell them to take the advice of everyone in the lab--everyone has a unique perspective, and oftentimes can provide insight to improve a prototype.I would also tell them to get to know the professors and mentors outside of class, since a positive relationship with them will be more conducive to future conversations about feedback. Also, they're amazing mentor figures outside of class, and are happy to talk about life outside of engineering 101.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: At the start of the class, the Tools Mastery segments were useful, and they facilitated my learning. I learned some useful skills related to prototyping. During the project, the instructors did not provide clear instructions or a vision for the project, so I was able to explore areas related to my project that I found interesting and useful. At the same time, due to unclear instructions and organization, grading and evaluation was unclear, leading to me being less focused on learning and more focused on understanding the instructors and the assignment. The highly structured format of most of the assignments was cumbersome and difficult to navigate and learn from.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There were lots of instructors, TAs, and mentors available for help and guidance. Having the progress of our 1YDE follow the curriculum also made it easier to understand the engineering design process.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that getting specific guidance from the teachers and TAs was really helpful in us trying to figure out different ways to approach our project. When we talked to our technical mentors, they helped us to broaden our perspectives and look for different methods to get our details set. Talking with Dr. Bletsch and Mr. Stach helped us figure out the materials that we could use for our product to get an organic feel and look. I would keep the idea of having the teachers walk around during class to give us guidance because it was helpful to have people come up to you and offer assistance instead of us having to go up to the teachers.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The assignments all followed a rigid structure, so there was no room for intellectual stimulation. All students had to follow the same format even though the format was not applicable to every format. It put teams into an intellectual box and stifled creativity when solving their assigned project. The project descriptions given to us at the start of the semester were vague and unclear, making it difficult to choose a project that I would know to be interesting to me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think this class really forced me to look at different perspectives to tackle what I thought was an easier project. We had to make a pitcher plant for our project, and so I didn't think that would be super challenging, but we still found ways to elevate the project in terms of how we created the organic form and how we incorporated the interactive elements. I think the class would have been more intellectually stimulating if I did have a technically harder project, however. Our project took lots of work, but we did not have to think extremely hard in how we were going to approach our final product.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors take a backseat in this course and give the groups a lot of independence to solve problems on their own, but they are always easily accessible if a group gets stuck. The TAs and LabRATS are great resources outside of class hours, especially for the Tools Mastery projects. I feel this system works well and lets the team lead their own learning process based on their project. The three-hour class blocks were rough at first, given the early stages of the design process don't lend themselves to long work blocks, but it was very helpful later in the process when prototyping and developing our product. Having 24-hour access to the POD is also incredibly helpful for keeping pace with the project, picking up prints, or just having a space to continue work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. G is always very available and will work with you to ensure that you understand a concept if you are experiencing a disconnect. The lectures were generally very helpful, however, some were spent entirely on teaching the background science or math rather than focusing on the code. This is not a result of the instructor wasting time, but more so the course itself being based of off concepts that many freshmen have not yet encountered or gained full comprehension of. The labs were always topical, and the style of the primary quiz for the course felt very intuitive for learning. The open/closed book and reflective nature of Skills Quiz 1 took off the pressure of a traditional exam and allowed me to see what my strengths and weaknesses were at that point in the course. Additionally, the reflection let me hone in on an improvement plan, which paid off for the remainder of the course. I highly recommend this style exam for this course, especially since coding is hardly ever done in the real world without additional/external resources. Dr. G also really cares about the well-being of students, and that was very appreciated by me and many others.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think this class was overly difficult and would be more intellectually stimulating if it were broken up.  Learning the engineering and mathematics with the new programming code was not easy at all.  Since the class combines the 3 aspects, it would be better if the three applications were broken up throughout the semester.  For example, teach the engineering part separate, then cover how to solve the mathematical problem, and lastly how to write it in code.  To make it more intellectually stimulating, videos with explanation and description would be helpful.  It would be helpful to have videos on someone actually doing the code and explaining what it is and why it is done that way.  Videos that show a motion picture or animation of an engineering problem/situation would be beneficial in providing a real example (that the student can deliberately see) of what is going on in a mathematical equation.As a beginner, I had no prior knowledge of Python or any coding software for that matter.  This class felt like treading on cracked ice.

Oftentimes, most of the work for the activities and labs would also have to be done outside of class in order to finish. The quizzes and labs were useful, essentially as practice to learn and put into place coding skills. Simultaneously, we would have a three-person project going on, in which we were meant to do research into a real-world issue, then write an algorithm for solving the problem, and then write code to solve it. The work for this was also done almost entirely outside of class. Class was used almost more like a help-room to work on algorithms/code and ask questions to the professor/TAs when needed.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would tell them to set team norms early, talk to their TAs before each project to avoid common pitfalls, and plan to finish projects a week in advance. My teams have never finished early; this seemingly extensive buffer time allowed my teams to react to injuries, or project components that took much longer than expected.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It does not matter what type of engineer you are. EGR121 gives fantastic baseline experience for technical knowledge and group collaboration abilities in all forms of engineering (namely mechanical and electrical). You dip your toes into various fun and engaging projects. Make good use of the TA office hours, as they are accomplished students with a good amount of technical experience under their belts. Ask the professors questions --- they are some of the most positive and supportive professors at this school.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don't procrastinate. You will regret it as the hours you need to put in are going to be long no matter what. When you are in a group try and take on as many roles as possible as it will only benefit you to get experience in all those skills.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. the importance of STEM education in children

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We developed the ability to think about inequities that exist in the ways STEM is taught to students. We also learned about the flaws in the ways the pathways to STEM are conceptualized, with the leaky pipeline being a misconception that perpetuates the idea that people passively fall out of the pathway to STEM rather than it being lack of access, resources, or harsh standards without proper help being given pushing people out. We also learned about the importance of one's STEM ecosystem, these being a collection of people who help an individual through their STEM journey.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the importance of inclusivity in STEM and how it can make younger people feel more confident in themselves and their abilities when they have a good foundation of STEM activities in their youth.  I also learned about how minorities are dealing with underrepresentation in STEM as they go on to university and how it effects their careers.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will sneak up on you with the work if you're not careful. Granted, aside from the weekly reflections and service learning requirement, there are only a few assignments. However, they are worth a lot of your grade, and the rubrics were pretty ambiguous. There are also lots of mini-projects you do during class that are quite impromptu and you don't get a lot of time to work on them, so be aware of that. Lastly, if you don't go to a service learning session one time, you may be a little lost during the thirty minutes during each class where you are preparing for it. Still, this is a very good course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

1. the importance of STEM education in children

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We developed the ability to think about inequities that exist in the ways STEM is taught to students. We also learned about the flaws in the ways the pathways to STEM are conceptualized, with the leaky pipeline being a misconception that perpetuates the idea that people passively fall out of the pathway to STEM rather than it being lack of access, resources, or harsh standards without proper help being given pushing people out. We also learned about the importance of one's STEM ecosystem, these being a collection of people who help an individual through their STEM journey.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the importance of inclusivity in STEM and how it can make younger people feel more confident in themselves and their abilities when they have a good foundation of STEM activities in their youth.  I also learned about how minorities are dealing with underrepresentation in STEM as they go on to university and how it effects their careers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Mike’s class focused on discussing real challenges and skills in professional life. Some of the key areas I feel like I solidified were:
- Decision making (using personal values to help make important decisions)
- Confidence (Professional Presence)
- Growth Mindset, Resilience, ability to ask for help and take advice

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how to make decisions in high pressure situations, how to carry and present myself in the workplace, and what skills to develop within myself to further my abilities as a leader.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In my opinion, the course was mostly about how to build character and presence and become the sort of person who would be a capable leader. It taught me so, so much about the importance of paying attention to how and what I communicate, how I can be a person of integrity, and how I can contribute meaningfully to society through my life and my work.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: What my values are, how to reflect on yourself, learning how to overcome failure and grow

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Metacognition/personal reflection, judgement, confidence, communication, and a lot more.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked how the class centered around key “themes” for each week. This helped frame the discussion from each speaker in my mind. I also thought it was very helpful that Mike and the speakers translated each theme into stories. I felt like talking about professional skills through the lens of personal experiences helped me connect those ideas to my life.The reflections were a great opportunity for me to actually take time and write down some of my thoughts about my interests, career aspirations, and observations from the speakers. I rarely take time to reflect, so having this opportunity was a gift.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class structure was very engaging and allowed me to have time to speak and play off of others' comments. This helped me to feel I was not only developing myself, but growing with others as a team. It helped me to see other perspectives and gave me practice speaking my thoughts in a professional sense. I liked the daily themes and the corresponding quotes, and I also liked having speakers from various fields. It really opened up my eyes to the versatility of leadership skills.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved coming into class every Thursday evening. I think that Mike and Blaire did a great job of creating an environment in which we all felt comfortable and empowered to share what we thought and to bounce ideas off of each other, and I really appreciate that I had a space and an opportunity to connect with my peers in this way. Even when we had guest speaker come in, some of whom were honestly really intimidating in how accomplished they were, it felt like we were able to just reach out and ask questions of them like we would a friend.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Keeping the guest speakers and the topics were good.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The discussions in class and the weekly reflections were both very helpful. I also liked the two coaching sessions since they forced me to reflect on the course as a whole and my growth over the course of the semester.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Mike’s personal advice, and the guest speakers he brought in were very interesting and felt personally relevant to my life. I felt like Mike did a good job distilling many professional skills into “nuggets” and key ideas to remember going into my career after college.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was stimulating because everyone was given the chance to speak, and we got to see the real application of these skills in the workplace.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I'd point out two things—one is the weekly reflections, and the second is the ability to discuss things in class. I personally loved writing the reflections—I'm fond of writing in general, and having the opportunity to reflect on myself and my own beliefs and character development every week in the context of what we learned in class was enlightening and inspiring. I really do think that writing the reflections every week kept me sane throughout a very hectic semester. The in class discussions had a similar effect, but with the additional factor of helping me to feel connected to the other students in a way that I think is hard to find elsewhere at Duke. And for both of these things, I am very grateful.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was cool to hear from the guest speakers and learn about their stories.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The variety of perspectives from the guest speakers, the other students, and Mike and Blaire made me think in new ways and also made me think how to apply concepts I was already familiar with to new circumstances.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course was a great opportunity develop progressional skills that are not taught in other engineering classes at Duke. Technical skills are very important, but communication skills are arguably equally important to having a successful and rewarding career. Mike’s class talked about these “softer skills” and helped me gain some key takeaways that I have already applied to my life and will continue to remember as I start my first job after school.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do it! It's fun, not a lot of work, but it gets you thinking and helps you check in with yourself.

response_text: Please take it! You'll love it and if you put some time into doing the reflections and holding the ideas of the class in your head and your heart, I think you'll come out with a better perspective of not only what you want to do, but who you want to become.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Bansal made the class engaging with live demos. She also wrote our her notes during lecture instead of reading off of a slideshow. That way, students can keep up with her work and attempt it themselves. She also made us do groupwork so we can practice the material as well. The labs were also pretty relevant to what we were learning in class that week. 1-2 problems were assigned for homework for each lecture which ensured we kept up with the course material, as well as extra practice material for quizzes. Instead of midterms, we had 5 quizzes and if we didn't score well enough, Dr. Bansal was very generous and would allow us to retake the quiz after proving mastery of that skill. This was so helpful and should be a policy continued for the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The lectures were very clear and helpful. The in-class group works were perfect for practicing the skills. The homeworks were good practice, and the extra problems were great practice for the quizzes. The re-quiz option was very helpful for me in forcing me to go back and review challenging material. The lab experiments were interesting and provided great practice with data analysis in Python as well as writing lab reports, and were well-aligned with lecture content.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: very very willing to help which was appreciated. i like the premise of the retakes and the entire driving ethos of the pundit

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. B is a fantastic lecturer, I don't think I've had a professor like her since coming to Pratt. She never made me feel silly for asking questions, and seemed to genuinely care whether or not I understood the fundamentals. I appreciate that she pushed us to always do the best work we possibly could, while holding us highly accountable for using AI or outside resources that might impede our learning in the long term. I also very much appreciated that she posted lecture recordings--I feel that some professors avoid this in order to retain class attendance, but I think because Dr. B has a hefty participation grade incorporated into the Syllabus, people didn't miss class. Also, because Dr. B is such a good lecturer, I genuinely wanted to come class to hear her lectures in person--I truly enjoyed this class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The way this course was structured was incredibly helpful to my learning. This class format was the best I've seen during my time at Duke, and I think we should keep it for future years. Each lecture was structured around one topic, then we did a group problem discussing the same topic. Then, for the homework, the main question was about the lecture topic but we had to use knowledge from prior weeks to solve it. This was incredibly efficient and allowed me to take lots of information in an easy-to-digest way.

response_text: Dr. Bansal is the ideal professor for a course like this. Every class she thoroughly explains a topic and leaves us with a short homework assignment and optional practice problems which I believe to be the best method for retention in a lecture like 201's. Her lectures themselves are also very interactive and open the space for collaboration on example problems which is such a good way to keep students attentive and interested.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The way this class was set up was amazing. The optional extra practice was great preparation for the quiz but again was truly optional because if you had an easy time with the in-class examples and HWs you could probably do well without it. The retakes were a game changer! It was so helpful to be able to take the quiz, get feedback, and then take a stab at the concepts again.

Springing a project on the class two days before Thanksgiving break that is due two days after thanksgiving break is completely ridiculous. She was unavailable and unhelpful throughout the semester, and it was very clear that she thinks she has better things to do than teach. It’s so frustrating because this should be fun, but the arbitrary grading and unclear expectations really ruined it for me.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about how forces and stresses impact structures. I learned how to break structures into parts and examine internal forces. I learned how to apply stress equations. I polished my free body diagram skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed how to view materials from an engineering standpoint. I learned how to use these concepts in real life through the labs. I learned how to use Mohr's circle.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Everything I learned was new. I have never learned anything about structures before this class, so everything to do with the forces were new. The only thing that I sort of knew ahead of time was free body diagrams, but even then, it was a bit different than what I had initially learned about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to visualize free body diagrams in two and three dimensions. I learned how to identify failure planes of a material. I learned how to analyze different material properties and how they interact with different forces.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that while I do not pay attention in lecture at all, I was able to teach myself the content very well by going to lab (problem solving sessions) and reviewing/redoing homework.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about forces on materials and how they act in response. We learned how to use equilibrium equations, Mohr's Circle, and how to find the maximum stress a beam can withstand before it buckles.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I broadened my knowledge about statics and material properties. This course taught me the basic principles to solve 2D and 3D practical engineering problems. I learned about factors of safety, solving for forces, stress, strain, methods of failure, and much more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to draw and analyze Free-Body Diagrams, including trusses and mechanisms. How to find stress and strain from normal, shear, torsion, and bending forces/torques. How to analyze stress and failure planes through Mohr's Circle

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to set up free body diagrams to solve word problems and then find the stress and strain. Finally, we use Mohr's circle to determine the failure planes of the surface.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: mechanics, statics, stress/strain, mohr's, failures

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to apply skills in physics to actually talking about materials and how they deform in real life. I learned how stress and strain can modify a material, and I learned how to systematically solve a problem.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This felt like my first "real" engineering course, and I really liked how the course applied many of the math and physics concepts we've learned to real-life scenarios such as trusses, frames and machines. 3 things I learned are equivalent force systems, solving truss systems, and finding stress states.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how draw free body diagrams, calculate normal and shear stress, and determine the failure plane on a differential area using Mohr's circle.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course gave me an important overview understanding of the ways in which structures fail and various forces interact with one another in various materials. Specifically, some of the highlights of the course content include Mohr's Circle and using it to analyze panes of failure, the different types of stress and strain and how they interact with a system, and how to calculate these values in a semi-complex system. This class also gave me more Lab and coding experience that I found useful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze structures, evaluate failure, and write lab reports.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think Dr. Nadeau's structure for the course worked really well. The order of topics was very logical, and everything built on what we've learned previously. The order didn't always match the textbook, but I thought that was an improvement. I think the discussion section was also a really helpful chance to apply the topics from lecture. My TA Shaan was great - he always had clear explanations and a very deep understanding of the concepts. His answers to my questions always made a lot of sense.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Course material was primarily taught through lecture, which despite being dull at times, still taught me a lot. Lecture notes were broken up by topic, contained all of the equations you needed, and provided examples problems. The problem solving sessions during lab were my favorite component of this class because it was a great way to learn how to solve practice problems (found this to be super helpful for completing the homework sets). I felt that the labs strayed a bit away from what was being taught in class and just sort of made for extra work, but they were still pretty interesting and it was a good introduction to engineering labs. It was clear what topics and types of problems to expect on the midterms - the practice exams posted in Canvas were an extremely helpful resource. Also, being able to use a cheat sheet on exams eased the stress of having to memorize equations and such. Overall, I really liked how this course was structured.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the lectures and in-class examples, which were very helpful when completing the homework and discussions. The pacing of the class was well set, if not slightly slow. The lab manuals were very straightforward, and the discussion problem sets were very true to the style and difficulty of questions seen throughout the class and exams.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The lectures were not very stimulating as the prof. went at a pretty slow pace and did not explain some of the concepts well near the end of the course. Additionally, we do three labs over the course of the semester but the first and second are basically identical in terms of the lab report portion, so I didn't find much value in copy and pasting the same code and graphs just for a different set of data.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
This class was not very intellectually stimulating for me. That is not to say that others did not enjoy it much more than I.
My usual experience was as follows: A derivation is performed which I, and most others, get lost during. Then there is a simple formula at the end which we memorize, having little idea as to why exactly it is used. That is our fault, as we could of course read the book or really try to delve into these derivations, but there is no incentive nor inspired desire to understand them.Once again, I think more enthusiasm from the speaker would help remedy this. I know that the speaker probably does find the subject at least somewhat interesting, but he does not show it. If he were to show it I think that many of us would feel more enthusiastic as well about the subject.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three methods to solve for equation of motion for dynamic systems. Actually learned quite a bit on solving diffy q, which I haven't taken as a course yet. Also deepened my intuition for how things should move.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reference frames when analyzing physics problems, how bodies and particles behave in motion, using math/differential techniques and solving equations of motion

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze rigid bodies and particles, how to find equations of motions, and how to use Matlab more proficiently for data analysis.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Dynamics, problem solving, physics, theoretical and analytical applications, experimentations

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to evaluate dynamic systems, derive equations of motion using a variety of methods, evaluate particle models and rigid body systems, apply dynamic models in a lab and real world setting, use different coding and algorithmic methods to solve for various values (experimentally and theoretically) and thoughtfully reflect and correct on my exam and quiz work.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to derive equations of motion. I learned how to create models based on real life data. And I learned how to perform different methods such as lagrangian to find EOMS.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to actually frame a problem statement in an engineering context, how to make assumptions that make finding a solution not only easier but also reasonably accurate, and to think about moving parts in engineering scenarios and model them mathematically and be able to describe what they are doing qualitatively.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was my favorite class at Duke so far. It was extremely challenging and a lot of work, but I feel like I have walked away from this class with an amazing foundation and a newfound passion for the subject.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Solving equations of motion, thinking like an engineer, seeing real world examples of theory

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-modeling complex systems with equations that describe its motion
-Techniques and thinking to approach problems in engineering through dynamics, including open-end/broad problems
-Problem solving, especially with challenging problems

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to approach a problem I haven't seen before and being able to break it down, make assumptions, and solve it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have learned how to determine a reference frame, how to apply Newton's and Euler's laws to create equations of motion, and Lagrange equation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Strengthened my method of problem solving, especially for complex problems. Taught me everything about Euler and Lagrange. Really strengthened my python skills to analyze data.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: learned about equations of motion, reference frames and vibrations

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to define and use reference frames, derive equations of motion of different systems with various methods (Newton's Laws, Euler's Laws, Lagrange's Equation), and how damping works and how oscillating systems behave.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: More nuanced analysis of physical scenarios using proper reference frames and coordinates along with new methods like Lagrange and Euler's 2nd Law. Learned to analyze harmonic motion in differential forms with damped and undamped natural frequencies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: LaGrange equations, working with relative reference frames, and Newtonian mechanics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Analyzing Motion Using Kinematics and Kinetics
2. Applying Work-Energy and Impulse-Momentum Principles
3. Deriving and Solving Equations of Motion

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Euler's Laws, Lagrangians, Numerical Methods with Python

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to define translational and rotational motion of particle systems in terms of custom coordinate systems and reference frames. The class taught me how to break down forces and behavior into divisible chunks for clearer analysis. I also learned interesting numerical methods for solving equations of motion using popular programming languages, and how to visualize these solved EoMs to determine validity. The use of simplifying assumptions was analyzed as a tool for success both in the classroom and the real world, and eventually the strengths and weaknesses of this approach was determined.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: There were a ton of things built into the course, but I think the main things were how to adopt my physics knowledge to dynamics, how to approach different problems, and doing thorough lab reports.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This is a very challenging semester for me and this course has very challenging content. But I was able to gain a good understanding on applying dynamics/physics into real life mechanics analysis. For example, in the pinewood derby car, I was able to related the structure of the vehicle with moment of inertia, analyze the motion dividing into translational and rotational phases, and most importantly, use well defined reference frames to analyze models.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to use reference frames, use ODEs to solve physics problems, and how to solve problem using multiple approaches (Euler's; Lagrange's etc)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really like how grades aren't curved in this class, so students aren't competing with each other. There is free collaboration on the corrections, collaborative quizzes, and hw by completion, all helped me to try to actually learn the material rather than grades.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Homework was relevant and helpful for staying on top of the content. Revisions for tests and quizzes helped me reflect and learn from my mistakes and created a positive learning environment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Douglas is incredible. You can tell he has a passion for teaching and really cares about his students. He was always very receptive to feedback, and never made anyone feel dumb for asking questions. I felt like the course components were properly suited. The homework wasn't too overwhelming and the lab reports were sometimes lengthy but doable. I really enjoyed the quiz's that we took in class but could go back and reflect and change our answers. I was able to talk amongst my classmates and hear how they approach problems because I didn't feel stressed about trying to get a perfect grade within that 20 minutes. Also test corrections were actually life changing. I have never gone back and looked at an exam in such detail, but test corrections made me do just that.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Revisions on quizzes and tests were helpful to correct mistakes and improve learning

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the revisions and corrections structure of exams and quizzes in this class. Having a grade incentive to return to my previous work, which was done in a stressful and time-constrained environment, and reevaluate my thought process, allowed me to notice areas of weak understanding and ensure that I had a solid foundation of the knowledge expected for that exam. It is something I want to do more often, but typically push aside for time reasons since other classes don't incentivize reflecting on previous work. I also felt that the labs tied in nicely with the lecture content and taught practical data analysis skills.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Keep the gravity car lab, as well as the labs in general. I very much liked the format of the take home midterm and exams. I learned a lot from going over my mistakes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Christopher Douglas was an amazing professor. His lectures were clear and interesting, and he was always available to answer questions outside class times as well as his designated office hours times. He would respond to emails within minutes. The assignments he made for homework or quizzes were at challenging in the moment, but extremely rewarding in the end. The assignments dealt with very real-world scenarios that made solving the problem so much more enjoyable. 
The fact that he allowed us to collaborate on and correct our midterms was amazing, I actually learned a great deal without the burden of doing well on tests. And his philosophy of having all of us collaborate rather than compete really resonated with the way I think.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Douglas is the most thoughtful and helpful professor I have had in my Duke career. He is extremely passionate about what he does, and it shows in every class. Is his class extremely hard? Yes. But it is fair, and if you put the work in, you will not only get a good grade in the class but you will develop a deep intuition for the subject that will help you far past your undergraduate career.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having test corrections rather than a curve was one of the things that helped me learn a lot. Being able to see what I got wrong and work through problems outside a testing setting again really helped me understand the mistakes I'd made, why they were wrong, and how the solution to a particular problem should look. I liked that tests in this class were used as a tool to gauge the students' understanding, and then we were given a chance to make sure that if we'd missed stuff, we would learn it by doing the corrections. This also made it much easier to keep up with the material and make sure I knew everything we had covered up to the exam. The group quizzes were also great since they encouraged collaboration and created an environment where the students could learn from each other. I really appreciated how this class emphasized teamwork and helping each other learn. Also, Professor Douglass very clearly wants his students to succeed and gives a lot of encouragement in class and makes getting extra help if you are struggling very easy. He is an awesome professor and made the class a lot of fun despite the challenging material.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The test and quiz correction system was instrumental to developing understanding of course material. Having the opportunity to go back and force yourself to understand your errors or give yourself extra time to apply new approaches was very helpful. Instructor was also very helpful at office hours through the week.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Labs were very useful as they applied our lectures to a real scenario.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The regular in-class problem-solving sessions were invaluable. Working through problems step-by-step, both individually and in groups, helped reinforce key concepts and provided immediate feedback. These sessions also allowed for collaborative learning, where students could learn from each other’s approaches.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The quiz/exam corrections really helped me understand my weaknesses and learn the material better while making tests less stressful. The gravity car lab was also very fun.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Douglas facilitates learning by focusing on examples in his lectures, rather than fuzzy concepts. He is very good at defining an approach or method, then pointing to how it can be used in a situation to solve a problem. The numerical methods practice in the homework was very interesting and taught not only how to numerically solve equations, but how to code systems and visualize them. The labs are also pretty interesting, and the lab report format is a good combination of analytical and programming work -- but usually, there is too much other work assigned in the class in the same period of time (homework AND a quiz correction) that sufficient time cannot be devoted to the lab, and instead it is seen as just another assignment to complete. The lab can be kept as is if the other problematic parts of the course are changed!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated that homework was more challenging than quizzes/tests and that we had room to learn because it was not graded on accuracy.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dynamics is a super difficult course in terms of the content, and Dr. Douglas did well in going through the content thoroughly and working through it with us. Writing out his notes and then posting them afterwards was super helpful and should be kept. Also having the opportunity to correct our quizzes and exams really amplified the learning environment, given I could try to work out the problems the first time in an exam environment and then go through and work through potential mistakes to understand better.

I learned a lot about the application of the material, and many of the problems, especially the homework, forced me to think about complex and difficult situations. I had to work closely with many other people in the class, which I enjoyed, but also added a level of difficulty to completing some of the assignments. Since we had a few extra lectures at the end of the semester, I would have loved to learn a little bit more about current research projects or other ways in which the subject we've been learning in class directly tie in to the work being done around us.
