question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's challenging but the grading is set up for you to succeed. Lab reports are time consuming and much-dreaded. You will come out with a solid understanding of dynamics in the end, though.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: One of the best courses, if not the best, I have taken at Duke. Definitely a hard class, but it is really worth it. I hope more classes were like this.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The content is difficult and you will need to be very engaged to understand it. That said, Professor Douglass cares a lot about his students and wants them to succeed. If you are struggling, go to office hours and he will be more than happy to help. Although the class is a lot of work, it's structured in a way that takes off a lot of the stress because homework is graded on effort, you get to do test corrections and get points back, and quizzes are done in groups. Students are heavily encouraged to work together and you will learn a lot from working with others.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Go to office hours for help with the homework since the problems are often easier than you think, you just need to have the confidence that your approach is correct. Start the labs early as well and follow the rubrics closely since the TAs are very harsh in grading.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! Its essential for understanding later MEC courses.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be ready to be confused.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: One of the tougher classes, but very rewarding. Exams are graded harshly with the expectation that most of the points will be made up with test corrections. I'd recommend finding a study group for those and the homework assignments.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The sheer quantity of work is very high for this course and unfortunately it is what you will remember from it. Expect to build on a base understanding of mechanics and statics. Expect to come away with the idea that many interesting dynamic systems can be solved, but you just don't know how.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

I imagine that he will be a very good prof to take dynamics with in the future after having a semester of experience under his belt.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Lecture was very strong, and posting of the notes was instrumental. TA Office Hours were also awesome, specifically Marianna's. She was excellent in teaching the concepts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The homeworks being graded on completion was nice, though I do feel that the homeworks were too difficult sometimes, as well as the labs. One thing in particular is that there were no rubrics for the labs or project which made the grading feel a bit arbitary and left us unsure about what exactly we needed to do. Half the battle is just finding out what we need to do and I feel like this made things unnecesarily difficult. I feel that the difficulty should come from challenging ourselves with concepts and not figuring out the details of a vague lab manual.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The format of going over questions in class, pausing and prompting questions, and the overall caring attitude of Prof. Santillan are aspects that genuinely boosted the learning environment positively. Her mastery of the subject is a clear and is certainly an asset in the structure of this course. Demonstrating more complicated/non-intuitive using apparatus that was brought to class was extremely helpful. The videos/prompt google searches were also great. More of this to develop an understanding of the subject is essential in my opinion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was consistently a lot of work week after week, which kept engagement high but was also difficult to actually learn from. The use of experiments in class and lab helped me understand the concepts, although I wish there was a bit more structure and outlining within the course. In the future, I would keep the lab component, but possibly discuss the implications of the lab in class to make sure the learning from it was as efficient as possible. I found the many office hours sections incredibly helpful throughout the course, and often went multiple times every week. I would keep the open-notes, group structure of the quizzes and labs as I found this very helpful. Group learinng and working with my peers to actually understand the concepts was a HUGE part of this class for me.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Design Thinking Process: Learned the structured phases of design thinking, including customer empathizing, opportunity definition, and solution ideation. Gained practical experience conducting stakeholder interviews and mapping value chains, which deepened the understanding of user-centered design.
Triple Bottom Line Analysis: Developed skills in evaluating business opportunities for their environmental, social, and economic impacts. This insight emphasized the importance of sustainability in innovation.
Entrepreneurship and Business Modeling: Acquired knowledge about creating business models, conducting market research, and pitching climate-tech ideas. This hands-on approach built confidence in entrepreneurial thinking and decision-making.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned many skills in entrepreneurship such as: how to conduct market research/market segmentation, how to conduct empathy interviews to understand stakeholder perspectives, and how design thinking can strengthen the process of trying to upscale a startup.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Technology developments that Duke and its partners are working on, as well as the climate technology ecosystem in Durham/NC.
- "Lean startup"-esque methods, such as beachhead markets and SWOT analysis
- Technical understanding of the climate challenge we tackled.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The main tangible I developed during this course is how to navigate "tough" entrepreneurial situations within the context of a team. 
(1) Communication skills - the ability to share, critique, and build upon others' ideas
(2) Discerning value from conversations - the ability to have a conversation with someone who may only tangentially relate to your project, but connect their expertise to the overarching mission of your project
(3) Storytelling - how to get someone to care about what you are doing, the "why" aspect of a startup

response_text:
Understanding the process of converting idea into product.

Market analysis and research

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Design Climate is a hands-on, interdisciplinary course where you’ll tackle real-world climate challenges through design thinking and collaboration with industry professionals. You’ll gain valuable skills in sustainability, business modeling, and project management while creating and pitching impactful solutions. The workload is significant but rewarding, and the experience looks great on a resume. If you’re passionate about climate innovation and ready to learn by doing, this course is a fantastic opportunity!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Design Climate I focuses on understanding the market, interviewing stakeholders, and conducting SWOT analyses, all of which are essential for any business. If you're only interested in building cool technical devices, this class may not be the best fit for you. However, if you want to create something meaningful from scratch—designing a product that addresses a user's pain point—then this is the perfect class for you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There are no design elements in this course. It is a marketing/entrepreneurship course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're interested in business, climate change, and engineering (design thinking), you should take this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Understand that while the projects you are working on are interesting, a lot of them are basically just filling a gap for an existing business or laying the groundwork for a potential nonprofit/business.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Only take this course if you are passionate about the topics. It will be more challenging and potentially detrimental to your team if you are not.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: - A crash course/simulation of developing a product, but not reflective of how things work in the "real world" or what it takes to develop a successful product; it will, however, give people a rough sense of the basics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are wondering "what content will be taught to me in this course" the answer is entrepreneurship 101. If you are looking to learn about a specific clean technology, whether it be related to renewable energy, infrastructure adaptation, sustainable materials, or sustainable business, it will not be taught to you. Further if you would like to apply engineering design, mechanical/electrical/chemical/computer engineering concepts, or any other area of academia, you will have to seek it out yourself. These realities, however, do reflect the real world. Just know what to expect.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: While the course teaches you a lot of things in a short time, and helps you learn new skills, it is a lot of work. We are students at the end of the day, so we are juggling many other things besides this course. Be mindful of the time commitment and only take this course when your other work is less intense. Or if you are extremely passionate about one of the projects.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: It's my first time in a business-related class, so I learned lots of new things in class, such as defining markets and costumes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking, Innovative thinking, Industry research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to conduct stakeholder interviews, how to pivot from idea to idea, and the difficult roadblocks that inevitably occur when turning a business into a reality.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned many skills in entrepreneurship such as: how to conduct market research/market segmentation, how to conduct empathy interviews to understand stakeholder perspectives, and how design thinking can strengthen the process of trying to upscale a startup.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Technology developments that Duke and its partners are working on, as well as the climate technology ecosystem in Durham/NC.
- "Lean startup"-esque methods, such as beachhead markets and SWOT analysis
- Technical understanding of the climate challenge we tackled.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The main tangible I developed during this course is how to navigate "tough" entrepreneurial situations within the context of a team. 
(1) Communication skills - the ability to share, critique, and build upon others' ideas
(2) Discerning value from conversations - the ability to have a conversation with someone who may only tangentially relate to your project, but connect their expertise to the overarching mission of your project
(3) Storytelling - how to get someone to care about what you are doing, the "why" aspect of a startup

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Understanding the process of converting idea into product. 
Creating a startup doesn't necessarily mean that innovator may have all the information and that it's okay
Market analysis and research

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like the nature of group work, and I think it would be beneficial to keep group work as this class moves forward.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course is an experiential learning course in that the goal of the course is to try to build out a climate tech startup. I felt sometimes the course structure(assignments, quizes, etc.) got in the way of the true goal. Intstructors were more focused on assignments and assessing the work we did than working WITH teams to guide and help development. I think there should be more collaboration going on between groups and instructors.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I very much enjoyed the design thinking workshop by the external consultant. I wish the class was more strongly informed by design thinking methodology rather than disciplined entrepreneurship.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the structure of the course because the assignments were all relevant to our learning for the course and for our advancing our potential business. I think we should have had lectures that focused more on how to conduct stakeholder interviews and providing a better structure prior to giving us the client list.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Constant support from instructors
Good theory accompanied with practise

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Instructor Support: The instructors provided clear guidance, responsive feedback, and encouraged collaboration. The availability of office hours and flexible scheduling supported deeper engagement.
Interdisciplinary Approach: Collaboration between students from different academic backgrounds enhanced problem-solving and creative thinking.
Project-Based Learning: The hands-on structure of the course, with real-world challenges and industry collaboration, made learning immersive and relevant.
Teamwork Emphasis: Group projects encouraged the development of teamwork and project management skills.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciate having a co-designer and community integrator for each project. The weekly co-designer meetings give me confidence that our project is headed in the right direction.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was hands-on so we were teaching ourselves. It was not effective since we lacked guidance and a clear direction.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think professors in class really help to provide a positive learning environment. The class is super well organized, and you can know what should do step by step, which is really helpful for people have no previous business background.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the instructions of this class is not that clear at first, and it seems like everything emerged were like a big mess, since the co-designer and professor seems have different demand for us and they didn't align with each other, which caused we always have no idea about the real direction of our product.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I believe having a field trip was extremely beneficial, as it allowed us to engage with the community and understand the problem. I also believe it was very helpful to have the instructors reach out to connections they know/find to help point us in the right direction.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Some assignments were more helpful than otgers for my learning. Specifically, market segmentation was helpful, as well as the stakeholder interviews. I also enjoyed the Disciplined Entrepreneurship reading, as it throughly explained many concepts that were previously unfamiliar to me. I also though the tabling event, and the field trip were both extremely beneficial is they provided hands-on experience with stakeholder engagement.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
- It was nice to work in a group setting with peers of different backgrounds
- The trip was actually an amazing experience and helped me engage with the community
- Professors helped students navigate ambiguous situations 
- It was oriented around doing
- I appreciated the close involvement of professors and tight feedback loops

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Working on one project throughout the semester allowed for a deep dive which I believe is very real and relevant to the entrepreneurial experience. In this way, course concepts such as market segmentation, SWOT analysis, beachhead market selection, prototyping etc., can be applied more powerfully.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the larger assignments which helped me get better acquainted with the process of innovation and design thinking.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think this class felt overwhelming at times? with the amount of interview, talking to stakeholders, and weekly co-designer meetings, weekly group meetings, and the homework it sometimes feels like it is a full time job and with the combo of other courses it feels suffering at times, so that was definitely stimulating, I guess it made me really good at time management.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The most stimulating part was not the course itself.  I enjoyed getting to work with our co-designer in the chemistry department. I loved hearing about his technology.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: So many assignments that force us to come up with answers/materials before we're ready.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think it could be more stimulating by encouraging more group activities that challenge our view on our potential market. Given that our class has a wide variety of business focuses, it would be nice to bring in a guest lecturer from a startup accelerator to give us advice.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: actual work with project, this demanded from us obtain new knowledge, acquire new skills

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
Enhanced Industry Engagement: Inviting more guest speakers from diverse fields of climate tech or arranging mentorship sessions could deepen intellectual stimulation.
Innovative Challenges: Incorporating cutting-edge climate topics like AI in sustainability or carbon capture technology could inspire forward-thinking solutions.
Gamified Elements: Adding gamified components, such as design competitions or innovation hackathons, could make the learning process even more dynamic.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class is definitely stimulating. The amount and type of work required demand an entrepreneurial mindset, which is very different from any other course I have taken.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We should first empathize with our customers and address a true problem that they have rather than trying to force fit our solution.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think because of no business background, this class is a new concept for me, so it is intellectually stimulation for me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Fortunately, we have real cases and product to develop.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think it was intellectually stimulating to consistently iterate the solution once unforeseen issues became apparent.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
Stimulating:
- Field trip, interviews, tabling events (occasions where we had the opportunity to pitch our work and understand pain points and potential solutions).
- Presenting work and receiving feedbackTo make more stimulating:
- More clearly demonstrate the signficance of the homework assignments and why they are necessary.
- More time for group work in class

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
- I think this class could have given students more room, time, and space to innovate and problem solve on their own and in a less set-in-stone time frame
- It might be more suitable for undergraduates or those very early in their careers.  For anyone who has had some professional experience, it can feel pretty stifling or taking a step back in terms of professional seriousness or rigor.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
What made this class stimulating:
The real-world feel of the class was something I had been craving out of school my whole life. You can't look up the answers to this class on Chegg! You have to look in the real world! This was incredibly an incredibly stimulating aspect.How could it be more intellectually stimulating:
More team building / alignment exercises / time-spent agreeing on what the project will look like. To be fair, this may be the fault of our Team Charter. However, I believe that that assignment could have been so much more than filling out the Team Charter template that the professors provided. We didn't realy talk about a way to come up with ideas and build them out. We didn't talk about how we were going to implement science and engineering into the course's assignments. If we had, there would have been more opportunity for intellectual stimulation.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Many assignments, especially those part of the business wayfinder, helped me think in new ways and challenge my assumptions. They were intellectually stimulating. However, they could've been better with some more time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to do a lot of work, but also have a lot of fun.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course has such amazing potential, though it is not quite refined yet. It needs to iterate before its vision is realized. Temper your expectations.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is time-consuming and emotionally taxing. We often find ourselves confused and frustrated as to why we're doing an assignment at this time because we haven't laid the groundwork for it (e.g., we're asked to do an assignment that assumes a solution when we haven't done enough research to understand the problem and ideate a solution).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think the student will get out what they put into this course. A lot of this course involves individualized student learning and outreach which takes on individual effort.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course, work in field is interesting and contribute to your development

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Design Climate is a hands-on, interdisciplinary course where you’ll tackle real-world climate challenges through design thinking and collaboration with industry professionals. You’ll gain valuable skills in sustainability, business modeling, and project management while creating and pitching impactful solutions. The workload is significant but rewarding, and the experience looks great on a resume. If you’re passionate about climate innovation and ready to learn by doing, this course is a fantastic opportunity!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Design Climate I focuses on understanding the market, interviewing stakeholders, and conducting SWOT analyses, all of which are essential for any business. If you're only interested in building cool technical devices, this class may not be the best fit for you. However, if you want to create something meaningful from scratch—designing a product that addresses a user's pain point—then this is the perfect class for you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There are no design elements in this course. It is a marketing/entrepreneurship course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're interested in business, climate change, and engineering (design thinking), you should take this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Understand that while the projects you are working on are interesting, a lot of them are basically just filling a gap for an existing business or laying the groundwork for a potential nonprofit/business.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Only take this course if you are passionate about the topics. It will be more challenging and potentially detrimental to your team if you are not.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: - A crash course/simulation of developing a product, but not reflective of how things work in the "real world" or what it takes to develop a successful product; it will, however, give people a rough sense of the basics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are wondering "what content will be taught to me in this course" the answer is entrepreneurship 101. If you are looking to learn about a specific clean technology, whether it be related to renewable energy, infrastructure adaptation, sustainable materials, or sustainable business, it will not be taught to you. Further if you would like to apply engineering design, mechanical/electrical/chemical/computer engineering concepts, or any other area of academia, you will have to seek it out yourself. These realities, however, do reflect the real world. Just know what to expect.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: While the course teaches you a lot of things in a short time, and helps you learn new skills, it is a lot of work. We are students at the end of the day, so we are juggling many other things besides this course. Be mindful of the time commitment and only take this course when your other work is less intense. Or if you are extremely passionate about one of the projects.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think reading Disciplined Entrepreneurship was a great way to learn about how to do market research. I learned about what e-methane was - I had no idea what e-methane was or what the market for it was prior to taking this course. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Design Thinking Process: Learned the structured phases of design thinking, including customer empathizing, opportunity definition, and solution ideation. Gained practical experience conducting stakeholder interviews and mapping value chains, which deepened the understanding of user-centered design.
Triple Bottom Line Analysis: Developed skills in evaluating business opportunities for their environmental, social, and economic impacts. This insight emphasized the importance of sustainability in innovation.
Entrepreneurship and Business Modeling: Acquired knowledge about creating business models, conducting market research, and pitching climate-tech ideas. This hands-on approach built confidence in entrepreneurial thinking and decision-making.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Design Climate is a hands-on, interdisciplinary course where you’ll tackle real-world climate challenges through design thinking and collaboration with industry professionals. You’ll gain valuable skills in sustainability, business modeling, and project management while creating and pitching impactful solutions. The workload is significant but rewarding, and the experience looks great on a resume. If you’re passionate about climate innovation and ready to learn by doing, this course is a fantastic opportunity!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

However, if you want to create something meaningful from scratch—designing a product that addresses a user's pain point—then this is the perfect class for you.

question_text: Please elaborate on your impressions of the quality of the course.
response_text: The course covered fundamental aspects of career strategy, which, as someone with four years of work experience, I found quite basic. I already had a strong grasp of the concepts presented and, in many cases, a deeper understanding from practical experience. As someone who has participated in hiring processes, managed a team, and hired multiple people, I had very minimal takeaways from this course.At times, it felt unnecessary to be in class, as I could have been working on more advanced or nuanced aspects of the subject. While I understand that this course may have been helpful for others in my cohort, I feel there would be value in dividing students into tailored groups based on experience and familiarity with the topic. This would allow us to build on our current knowledge more effectively, rather than being placed in cohorts with varying levels of understanding.

response_text: The instructor demonstrated solid expertise and delivered the preset course material effectively. However, I felt there was a missed opportunity in not taking the initial classes to assess the diverse backgrounds and levels of understanding that students brought to the course. For instance, providing industry-specific insights or allowing for different projects based on student profiles could have bridged the gap between foundational content and the practical challenges faced by those with prior experience. This adjustment could help students at all levels feel engaged and supported, leading to a more dynamic and inclusive learning environment.Overall, the instructor's knowledge was evident, but a more adaptable and tailored approach could have further elevated the course experience.

question_text: What parts of the class were least useful for you? Why?
response_text: What I liked least about the class was the emphasis on extrovert-enabler warming-up activities. While these activities can be beneficial for many students, they might not be comfortable for introverted individuals. To improve the course, I would recommend incorporating a variety of activities that cater to both introverted and extroverted students. Additionally, I felt that the class missed covering cover letter writing, which is an essential component of job applications. It would have been beneficial to include this topic within the class modules to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the job application process.

question_text: Please add any additional comments or suggestions for improving the learning experience in this course.
response_text:
(1) Enhanced Focus on Cover Letters
While the course extensively covered resume building and LinkedIn profiles, dedicating some time to cover letter creation would be beneficial. Crafting compelling cover letters is a crucial skill in the job application process, and it would complement the other aspects of professional development taught in the course.(2) Diversity in Learning Styles
It would be helpful to recognize that students have varying learning styles (e.g., extrovert and introvert student). Some may thrive in interactive warm-up activities, while others might prefer a more structured approach. Offering a balance or allowing students to choose between different approaches could make the course even more inclusive.(3) Advanced Professional Development 
Given the success of this course, considering more advanced coursework could be a valuable next step. Topics could include understanding U.S. working culture, assessing job offers comprehensively, and negotiating compensation packages. These insights would be especially beneficial for international students like me who are navigating a new job market.

question_text: Please add any additional comments or suggestions for improving the learning experience in this course.

response_text: The timing at which this course was scheduled- i.e., mid- semester (cohort B). Asians (who form over 70% of the class) often begin their internship efforts in the month of June-August. question_text: Please elaborate on your impressions of the quality of the course.
response_text: I wouldn’t say I took too much from this course, but it’s certainly a situation of you get what you put in. Jenny and Cameo were amazing instructors, and I spoke to a lot of people who found immeasurable value in their time here, and I had fun connecting with other MEMs. I feel like I’ve heard the interview/resume advice a million times, and at this point, I’m frustrated with the whole system; thinking about my career objectives just cause me stress. However, there are others who have heard this advice for the first time I think I personally would have benefited from in-class time to search for jobs, but I do know from conversations that others preferred it this way.Overall, this is a valuable claaa for some, and I really appreciated the grading/attendance flexibility that prevented it from adding a ton of stress to my semester, especially as a one credit course.

The supportive classroom environment she has created encourages students to explore different career paths and possibilities with confidence. Her enthusiasm for the subject matter is contagious, sparking a genuine interest in career design that many students didn't have before taking her class. Professor Johnson's ability to encourage critical thinking about career choices and provide tools for informed decision-making is particularly valuable, preparing students for success in their future careers.

question_text: Open-Ended QuestionsWhat parts of the class were most useful for you? Why?
response_text:
The most useful parts of the Special Topic Career Design class were the practical exercises and real-world applications. The self-assessment tools we used helped me gain a deeper understanding of my strengths, values, and interests, which was crucial in aligning my career goals with my personal attributes. These exercises provided a solid foundation for making informed decisions about my future career path.
Additionally, the guest speaker sessions and case studies were incredibly valuable. Hearing from professionals in various fields gave me insights into different career trajectories and the realities of different industries. The class discussions that followed these sessions allowed me to critically analyze different career options and consider aspects I hadn't previously thought about. The hands-on resume building and interview preparation workshops were also extremely practical, equipping me with tangible skills that I can immediately apply in my job search process.

question_text: What parts of the class were least useful for you? Why?
response_text: Some of the discussion boards on objective statements felt pointless. I'm pretty sure 80% of the class ChatGPTed this one. question_text: What parts of the class were least useful for you? Why?

question_text: What parts of the class were least useful for you? Why?

question_text: What parts of the class were least useful for you? Why?

question_text: What parts of the class were least useful for you? Why?

question_text: What parts of the class were least useful for you? Why?
response_text: The resilience and portfolio classes were least useful to me, since I am not doing a design-based career, and the resilience class I was texting a friend from home the whole time and was technically on task because one of the strategies was "nurture relationships" It was a good thing to go over, but not worth a whole class period

question_text: What parts of the class were least useful for you? Why?
response_text: The group discussion format doesn't work in classes in my opinion. Students aren't going to take it seriously. It makes sense in instances like interview practice or career fair approaches. Talking with your neighbor about the Gallup big 5 strengths is not intellectual conversation. Almost every time this happened, which was a lot, it was always unserious. Remove the focus on the strengths or actually dig into it more. Its so surface level there is really no thought into that. Back on the group discussion, things like that and other group discussions like work in your groups on these ideas were a waste of time. Again it was not serious. The class was too large in my opinion. You need to decrease the size for it to really make an impact. The lack of impactful assignments also was not great. The big four assignments should be a requirement for completion of the course, more assignments should be incorporated, and they shouldn't be for completion but actually some sort of loose grading component so there actual stake.If we are going to do the big classes with group discussion. Make assigned seating or something, so unique conversation forms each class.

question_text: What parts of the class were least useful for you? Why?

question_text: What parts of the class were least useful for you? Why?
response_text: Most of the course was working on sentences and learning about the resources we have to do the course. I felt that was a waste of time instead of applying to jobs or taking that time to reach out to employers.

question_text: Please elaborate on your impressions of the quality of the course.
response_text:
The course helped me reflect on my strengths and weaknesses. I was not very sure of the companies that I would be applying to. The LAMP list helped me understand how to apply to the company and the purpose of prioritization of the applications. It also helped me navigate my way through the applications and make industry connections.  The course helped me understand what I prioritize the most in jobs and the kind of company and culture I would be looking for. The questions that can be asked to the interviewer were one of the things that were the most helpful to me and I even implemented those suggestions in my interview.
I found CSPD to be a very well-designed course that gave me a holistic overview of what I seek from my professional life and the steps to achieve my goals. Everything, right from discovering my strengths and weaknesses to practicing negotiations in the class turned out to work really well for me.

question_text: Please elaborate on your impressions of the quality of the course.
response_text: The course is centered on a combination of English presentations and cultural insights aimed at facilitating a seamless experience for international students. I found the course immensely valuable, especially for those unfamiliar with American culture and encountering challenges in English proficiency and public speaking. If you already possess an intermediate language level or have prior experience living in the USA or a similar environment, you may not find it as beneficial, as it covers basic aspects. Personally, I was anticipating a more in-depth exploration of presentation skills, which was my primary focus, rather than an emphasis on cultural adaptation.

question_text: Please elaborate on your impressions of the quality of the course.
response_text: This course has proven to be highly beneficial for non-native speakers of English. As a first-time English class participant, the opportunity to learn alongside other non-native English speakers has been invaluable in mitigating feelings of discouragement. The inclusive learning environment created in this course fosters a sense of camaraderie among students facing similar language challenges.Moreover, the course instructor imparts practical English writing skills, providing valuable insights and techniques. The mandatory English writing exercises have played a pivotal role in honing my abilities and significantly enhancing my proficiency. The structured approach to writing exercises, coupled with the practical tips shared during the course, has not only made the learning process enjoyable but has also contributed substantially to my overall improvement in English writing. I am grateful for the supportive and constructive learning environment that this course has offered.

question_text: Please add any additional comments or suggestions for improving the learning experience in this course.
response_text: As a context, I am taking an EGR 790 course (PhD English Writing for Engineers) this semester. It has been very helpful to improve my writing to communicate with clarity (for/in) my science. We meet twice a week (2.30 hours). It was brought to my attention that this course is not graded even though I am putting in the same hours for my stats class (STA 611) per week. I know that the writing class is required for my PhD but it does not count towards my degree. For this reason, I wonder if you could provide more information on why the writing course does not count towards my degree when I am putting the same hours as in my stats class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Dr. Walker presented many useful skills during our classes including, the Founder's Framework, the importance of vulnerability in relationships, and the many ways in which to learn effectively.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: During this course, I learned how to understand, work with, and build relationships with people. This class offered a unique space to learn among a small group of people, allowing us to build relationships and engage in the class and college together. Also, I learned more about metacognition and entrepreneurship. I like the emphasis that was put on reflection throughout the semester as that is a skill I will take out of this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think the best part of the course (and honestly only part I found useful) was life stories. That was really great and is something I am asking my friends now. Honestly life-changer. Everything else - the wellness stuff, ect. I found pretty useless. I do think it was a good forcing function for us to get together and we typically get dinner afterwards which is nice.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed a deeper understanding of myself and how to approach life with intention and balance. I learned valuable habits to improve my learning, such as time management strategies and techniques to enhance focus and productivity, which have already made a noticeable difference in my academic performance. The course also helped me build emotional intelligence by teaching me how to recognize and manage my emotions, communicate effectively, and build meaningful relationships. Additionally, I gained confidence and practical tools to navigate Duke with proficiency, from understanding available resources to building connections within the community. Overall, this experience encouraged me to reflect on what it means to be a better person—fostering empathy, resilience, and a mindset of continual growth in both my personal and academic life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Communication; vulnerability in a fresh group setting; coping mechanisms.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Developing openness allowed me to explore new ideas, perspectives, and methods of learning. I found that by listening actively and being receptive to feedback, I could refine my understanding and enhance my skills. This mindset encouraged me to step out of my comfort zone, whether it was experimenting with unfamiliar problem-solving techniques or engaging in discussions that challenged my viewpoints. 
Learning to practice gratitude helped me recognize and appreciate the value in everyday experiences, both big and small. Whether it was acknowledging the effort of a teammate or being thankful for feedback, this perspective allowed me to focus on positive outcomes, even in challenging situations.
Embracing vulnerability taught me the strength in admitting when I don’t know something or need help.This approach also helped me connect with peers and instructors on a more personal level, creating a supportive learning environment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Walker contributes insightful wisdom in a smaller group discussion setting that allows the students to engage with him and the others in the class. He leaves room for disagreement and discussion and draws from his own expansive experience in answering questions. He does a good job of querying other to see what they are thinking and towards the later half of the class, does a great job of including everyone in the discussion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed how each class was free to be a discussion. Though we talked more some days than others, I appreciated that we were always free to contribute to the lesson and conversation, as well as our thoughts and perspectives were valued.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The learning environment of this class was incredibly engaging and supportive, largely due to Dr. Walker’s approach to facilitating open dialogue. Her method of speaking directly with the class, encouraging us to ask questions and engage in discussions, created a dynamic and interactive atmosphere that kept us invested in the material. One standout component was the activity involving hurricanes, where we had to decide the order of importance for various items. This exercise was a perfect demonstration of how to work effectively in a team by emphasizing the importance of having a structured process and clear communication. Activities like this should absolutely be kept for future years, as they not only reinforced course concepts but also provided a practical, hands-on way to apply what we learned in a collaborative setting.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Bill did an excellent job facilitating an atmosphere in which all students feel welcome and encouraged to participate. He develops skills within all students in the seminar to equally facilitate this atmosphere. Honestly, I have a feeling this is one of the best courses I'll ever take at Duke. I am beyond grateful for the opportunity to share my life story, as all students were encouraged to do, as well as try out coping skills, organization techniques, and communication methods within an intimate group setting --- a rare thing to attain, particularly in one's first year as an engineering student.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: One of the most memorable and effective aspects of the class was when everyone shared their personal stories and what they value in life. This component not only built trust among classmates but also helped me reflect on my own values, and I strongly recommend keeping it in future years as it creates a supportive and empathetic learning environment. The metacognition lesson was incredibly valuable, as it helped me reflect on my thought processes, identify strengths and areas for growth, and improve my approach to learning. This skill has made me a more intentional learner and should definitely be included in future years.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made the class stimulating was Dr. Walker's own point of view of his experience and the thoughtful insight he offers coupled with the reasons he thinks the way he does. This provides a compelling argument that makes a student truly consider what he is posing.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made this class stimulating was building relationships with classmates and the instructor. Getting to know each other allowed us to have deeper conversations and dependence on each other in and outside the class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating because it encouraged deep self-reflection and practical application of the skills we learned, such as improving habits, navigating challenges, and fostering emotional intelligence. The open dialogue and interactive activities kept the material engaging and relevant. It balanced intellectual and personal growth perfectly, making it both thought-provoking and impactful. Nothing significant needs to be changed, as the course already achieves a high level of intellectual and emotional stimulation.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I could be deep and was encouraged to express my own approach to things, as well as listen openly to and consider others' approaches. There were no wrong answers, and everything put into the group discussion table was up to interpretation and respectful reaction from all.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Walker contributes insightful wisdom in a smaller group discussion setting that allows the students to engage with him and the others in the class. He leaves room for disagreement and discussion and draws from his own expansive experience in answering questions. He does a good job of querying other to see what they are thinking and towards the later half of the class, does a great job of including everyone in the discussion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed how each class was free to be a discussion. Though we talked more some days than others, I appreciated that we were always free to contribute to the lesson and conversation, as well as our thoughts and perspectives were valued.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The learning environment of this class was incredibly engaging and supportive, largely due to Dr. Walker’s approach to facilitating open dialogue. Her method of speaking directly with the class, encouraging us to ask questions and engage in discussions, created a dynamic and interactive atmosphere that kept us invested in the material. One standout component was the activity involving hurricanes, where we had to decide the order of importance for various items. This exercise was a perfect demonstration of how to work effectively in a team by emphasizing the importance of having a structured process and clear communication. Activities like this should absolutely be kept for future years, as they not only reinforced course concepts but also provided a practical, hands-on way to apply what we learned in a collaborative setting.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Bill did an excellent job facilitating an atmosphere in which all students feel welcome and encouraged to participate. He develops skills within all students in the seminar to equally facilitate this atmosphere. Honestly, I have a feeling this is one of the best courses I'll ever take at Duke. I am beyond grateful for the opportunity to share my life story, as all students were encouraged to do, as well as try out coping skills, organization techniques, and communication methods within an intimate group setting --- a rare thing to attain, particularly in one's first year as an engineering student.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: One of the most memorable and effective aspects of the class was when everyone shared their personal stories and what they value in life. This component not only built trust among classmates but also helped me reflect on my own values, and I strongly recommend keeping it in future years as it creates a supportive and empathetic learning environment. The metacognition lesson was incredibly valuable, as it helped me reflect on my thought processes, identify strengths and areas for growth, and improve my approach to learning. This skill has made me a more intentional learner and should definitely be included in future years.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Design Thinking Process: Learned the structured phases of design thinking, including customer empathizing, opportunity definition, and solution ideation. Gained practical experience conducting stakeholder interviews and mapping value chains, which deepened the understanding of user-centered design.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned many skills in entrepreneurship such as: how to conduct market research/market segmentation, how to conduct empathy interviews to understand stakeholder perspectives, and how design thinking can strengthen the process of trying to upscale a startup.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Technology developments that Duke and its partners are working on, as well as the climate technology ecosystem in Durham/NC.
- "Lean startup"-esque methods, such as beachhead markets and SWOT analysis
- Technical understanding of the climate challenge we tackled.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The main tangible I developed during this course is how to navigate "tough" entrepreneurial situations within the context of a team. 
(1) Communication skills - the ability to share, critique, and build upon others' ideas
(2) Discerning value from conversations - the ability to have a conversation with someone who may only tangentially relate to your project, but connect their expertise to the overarching mission of your project
(3) Storytelling - how to get someone to care about what you are doing, the "why" aspect of a startup

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Understanding the process of converting idea into product. 
Creating a startup doesn't necessarily mean that innovator may have all the information and that it's okay
Market analysis and research

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
What made this class stimulating:
The real-world feel of the class was something I had been craving out of school my whole life. You can't look up the answers to this class on Chegg! You have to look in the real world! This was incredibly an incredibly stimulating aspect.How could it be more intellectually stimulating:
More team building / alignment exercises / time-spent agreeing on what the project will look like. To be fair, this may be the fault of our Team Charter. However, I believe that that assignment could have been so much more than filling out the Team Charter template that the professors provided. We didn't realy talk about a way to come up with ideas and build them out. We didn't talk about how we were going to implement science and engineering into the course's assignments. If we had, there would have been more opportunity for intellectual stimulation.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Design Climate is a hands-on, interdisciplinary course where you’ll tackle real-world climate challenges through design thinking and collaboration with industry professionals. You’ll gain valuable skills in sustainability, business modeling, and project management while creating and pitching impactful solutions. The workload is significant but rewarding, and the experience looks great on a resume. If you’re passionate about climate innovation and ready to learn by doing, this course is a fantastic opportunity!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Design Climate I focuses on understanding the market, interviewing stakeholders, and conducting SWOT analyses, all of which are essential for any business. If you're only interested in building cool technical devices, this class may not be the best fit for you. However, if you want to create something meaningful from scratch—designing a product that addresses a user's pain point—then this is the perfect class for you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There are no design elements in this course. It is a marketing/entrepreneurship course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're interested in business, climate change, and engineering (design thinking), you should take this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Understand that while the projects you are working on are interesting, a lot of them are basically just filling a gap for an existing business or laying the groundwork for a potential nonprofit/business.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Only take this course if you are passionate about the topics. It will be more challenging and potentially detrimental to your team if you are not.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: - A crash course/simulation of developing a product, but not reflective of how things work in the "real world" or what it takes to develop a successful product; it will, however, give people a rough sense of the basics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are wondering "what content will be taught to me in this course" the answer is entrepreneurship 101. If you are looking to learn about a specific clean technology, whether it be related to renewable energy, infrastructure adaptation, sustainable materials, or sustainable business, it will not be taught to you. Further if you would like to apply engineering design, mechanical/electrical/chemical/computer engineering concepts, or any other area of academia, you will have to seek it out yourself. These realities, however, do reflect the real world. Just know what to expect.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: While the course teaches you a lot of things in a short time, and helps you learn new skills, it is a lot of work. We are students at the end of the day, so we are juggling many other things besides this course. Be mindful of the time commitment and only take this course when your other work is less intense. Or if you are extremely passionate about one of the projects.

response_text:
The main tangible I developed during this course is how to navigate "tough" entrepreneurial situations within the context of a team. 
(1) Communication skills - the ability to share, critique, and build upon others' ideas
(2) Discerning value from conversations - the ability to have a conversation with someone who may only tangentially relate to your project, but connect their expertise to the overarching mission of your project
(3) Storytelling - how to get someone to care about what you are doing, the "why" aspect of a startup

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Understanding the process of converting idea into product. 
Creating a startup doesn't necessarily mean that innovator may have all the information and that it's okay
Market analysis and research

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course is an experiential learning course in that the goal of the course is to try to build out a climate tech startup. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
